data.title: Disneyâ€™s animated book-to-film adaptations, ranked by faithfulness
data.meta_description: The Little Mermaid, The Great Mouse Detective, The Princess and the Frog â€”Â they were all based on books. We ranked which ones most respect the source stories.
data.text:
Right from the beginning, Walt Disney Animation Studios leaned heavily on existing books and stories for inspiration, starting with its first feature, 1937â€™s Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. While this has resulted in some truly wonderful movies, the studioâ€™s tendency to make major changes to its source material â€” toning down the original storiesâ€™ dark or violent content, and generally softening the edges â€” has also been apparent from the start.

A Century of Disney

Weâ€™re deconstructing the monolith all year long

Read more

Itâ€™s such a predictable part of the Disney process that the neologism â€œDisneyficationâ€ has become a generic term for bowdlerizing a story into a tame kid-friendly version. Hereâ€™s a comprehensive rundown of Disneyâ€™s animated movies that are based on existing stories, noting the often surprising differences between the two, and ranking them in order from most faithful to least faithful.

25. The Great Mouse Detective (1986)

Based on: Eve Titus and Paul Galdoneâ€™s series Basil of Baker Street (1958-1982)

The Great Mouse Detective is an underrated gem that appears to have grown in both popularity and stature over the years, and itâ€™s one of a few instances of Disney adapting material from a series of books, mixing storylines together. (In live action, you can see this clearly in movies like Mary Poppins, which is drawn from a series of eight books by P.L. Travers.) There arenâ€™t many major differences between the books and the movie, save that the main character â€” Basil, essentially a mouse version of Sherlock Holmes â€” is a little less temperamental in the books. And curiously, unlike his inspiration, he plays the flute. Given that Basil actually lives in the same house as Holmes, who plays violin, this seems like an odd alteration.

24. Bambi (1942)

Based on: Felix Saltenâ€™s novel Bambi, a Life in the Woods (1923)

There are plenty of subtle, yet significant, alterations in Bambiâ€™s trip from page to screen. Both versions start with Bambiâ€™s birth, but in the book, itâ€™s treated as no special event. Thumper and Flower are Disney creations, while Friend Hare and Falineâ€™s twin brother Gobo didnâ€™t make it into the movie. The death of Bambiâ€™s mother, a scene that traumatized generations of children, comprises only a single line in the novel, and thereâ€™s no forest fire in the book.

23. The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad (1949)

Based on: Kenneth Grahameâ€™s novel The Wind in the Willows (1908) and Washington Irvingâ€™s short story â€œThe Legend of Sleepy Hollowâ€ (1820)

Disneyâ€™s anthology film The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad features condensed versions of its source material. For the Wind in the Willows segment, Toad stealing a car and escaping from jail is out, and a talking-horse character is added in. Unusually, the bookâ€™s ending is happier than the filmâ€™s, but overall, the two arenâ€™t so dissimilar. The Legend of Sleepy Hollow section is one of the most accurate Disney interpretations, with the general feel of book and film matching closely. Even the original storyâ€™s ambiguous ending is present and correct.

22. Alice in Wonderland (1951)

Based on: Lewis Carrollâ€™s novels Aliceâ€™s Adventures in Wonderland (1865) and Through the Looking-Glass (1871)

Itâ€™s a little difficult to evaluate this one, because Disney drew elements from two books and jumbled them up, mixing the timelines and making plenty of minor adjustments throughout â€” like Disney having Alice eat cakes to become smaller, rather than carrots, as in the source material. In the book, Alice is asked to recite the poem â€œYou Are Old, Father William,â€ while the movie changes this to â€œHow Doth the Little Crocodileâ€ (although both poems are by Lewis Carroll himself). Characters say lines originally spoken by different characters; the King of Hearts is nice rather than mean; a couple of executions are left out; and two of Carrollâ€™s most memorable characters, Mock Turtle and Gryphon, are omitted entirely (and therefore, so too is Mock Turtleâ€™s wonderful song-and-dance act).

21. Cinderella (1950)

Based on: Charles Perraultâ€™s short story â€œCinderellaâ€ (1697)

While the major plot arc here is the same, Perraultâ€™s version leaves Cinderellaâ€™s father alive and very much under her stepmotherâ€™s thumb. There are no talking animal friends to be found in the book, Cinderella has a nicer room, the youngest stepsister is not so mean, and the princeâ€™s mother is still alive as well. There are two royal balls in the original version (Cinderella only flees from the second), and the ending is more forgiving, with Cinderella inviting her stepsisters to come live in the palace once she marries the Prince, and finding them lords to marry as well.

20. Sleeping Beauty (1959)

Based on: Charles Perraultâ€™s short story â€œThe Sleeping Beauty in the Woodsâ€ (1697)

There are some very telling alterations between Charles Perraultâ€™s original â€œSleeping Beautyâ€ and Disneyâ€™s interpretation, ones that perfectly sum up Walt Disneyâ€™s approach of taking an original story and ramping the romance factor up to 11 while keeping â€œtraditionalâ€ values intact. For starters, Disneyâ€™s version has the prince and princess coming from the same era and knowing each other before she falls asleep, whereas Perraultâ€™s princess sleeps for a century, so sheâ€™s much older than her beau. There is no â€œtrue loveâ€™s kissâ€ in the short story â€” all the prince has to do is show up, and Sleeping Beauty awakens. Perraultâ€™s fairies grant the princess gifts of wit, grace, dancing, singing and music. Disney leaves out the wit!

19. 101 Dalmatians (1961)

Based on: Dodie Smithâ€™s novel The Hundred and One Dalmatians (1956)

Some characters from Dodie Smithâ€™s novel are omitted or altered for the film, but the big difference here is Disneyâ€™s toning down of Cruella de Vil, whoâ€™s a much darker character on the printed page. Gone is Cruellaâ€™s white Persian cat, who tells a very sorry story of years of neglect and abuse from her mistress, who periodically drowned the catâ€™s kittens. Cruellaâ€™s lines are also watered down â€” some of them are pretty extreme in the book, which also contains a lot of background and context that never made it to the screen.

18. The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh (1977)

Based on: A.A. Milneâ€™s short-story collection Winnie-the-Pooh (1926)

The biggest difference here is the visuals, with original Pooh illustrator E.H. Shepardâ€™s monochrome line drawings translated to Disneyâ€™s full-color style. Normally, this might not matter so much, but Shepardâ€™s less-is-more drawings add a particular atmosphere that is lost in the movies. The American accents alter things as well. Rabbit is a much-changed character, while Gopher is a Disney invention. Perhaps the biggest alteration is the omission of Milneâ€™s songs, which are replaced by upbeat showtunes.

17. Peter Pan (1953)

Based on: J.M. Barrieâ€™s play Peter Pan; or, The Boy Who Wouldnâ€™t Grow Up (1904) and novel Peter and Wendy (1911)

Disney considerably altered Peter Panâ€™s personality; in Barrieâ€™s original work, the character is much meaner and even more self-centered. In the book, Peterâ€™s motives stem from selfishness. He tolerates John and Michael Darling only because he wants to spend time with Wendy. Tinker Bell, by contrast, is far more capricious in Disneyâ€™s hands than in Barrieâ€™s. The climactic fight between Peter and Captain Hook, and the bookâ€™s ending â€” no spoilers â€” are far more intriguing than those in the film.

16. The Jungle Book (1967)

Based on: Rudyard Kiplingâ€™s short story collection The Jungle Book (1894)

In The Jungle Book, Disney altered the dark, serious tone of pretty much all of the characters and their relationships as they stand in Rudyard Kiplingâ€™s work. In the original stories, Mowgli goes naked, expressing disdain for even a loincloth, and his relationship with Bagheera is far more equal. Kipling depicts Kaa as arguably Mowgliâ€™s wisest and most helpful companion. King Louie is completely absent. Baloo, far from being frivolous and hedonistic, is a sweet caretaker who teaches Mowgli the Law of the Jungle. Shere Khan, on the printed page, is as pitiful as he is frightening.

15. The Rescuers (1977)

Based on: Margery Sharpâ€™s novels The Rescuers (1959) and Miss Bianca (1962)

The Rescuers is another case of Disney taking material from more than one book. Plenty of things change from novels to screen here, big and small. Sharpâ€™s Black Castle becomes Disneyâ€™s Devilâ€™s Bayou; Madam Chairwoman becomes Mr. Chairman. The original plot, which involved the titular mouse heroes rescuing a Norwegian poet, is dropped. So too are the bookâ€™s passages concerning the class difference between Miss Bianca and Bernard, which prevents them from ever being more than friends. This film had a long and tortuous road to the screen, with multiple revisions to remove any hint of the original workâ€™s politics.

14. Treasure Planet (2002)

Based on: Robert Louis Stevensonâ€™s novel Treasure Island (1883)

Leaving aside the setting, which Disney reimagines as a kind of steampunk sci-fi/fantasy world, the main differences between Treasure Island and Treasure Planet lie in the character of Long John Silver, and in Disneyâ€™s expunging of the violence present in the original. Stevensonâ€™s Silver is far more dangerous and morally ambiguous. Disneyâ€™s world is a much safer place, and in the studioâ€™s hands, Jim Hawkins is a tamer, more obedient character. Once again, slight yet important changes to the protagonistâ€™s personality mean that the spirit of the original is drastically altered.

13. Tarzan (1999)

Based on: Edgar Rice Burroughsâ€™ novel Tarzan of the Apes (1914)

Disney significantly softened the personality of its protagonist for Tarzan. The Tarzan of the book is considerably more violent. Thereâ€™s quite a bit of violence throughout the novel, with murderous fights between Tarzan and various animals, villains, and natives, the latter of whom are grossly portrayed as caricatures. Tarzan of the Apes also contains several chapters dealing with events after Tarzan and Jane leave the jungle, largely concerning Tarzanâ€™s impressions of the â€œcivilizedâ€ world, and the claiming of his birthright.

12. The Black Cauldron (1985)

Based on: Lloyd Alexanderâ€™s series The Chronicles of Prydain (1964-1969)

The descriptions of The Black Cauldronâ€™s characters in the books are completely different from those on screen. The mythical races are also changed, with Disneyâ€™s Gwythaints looking like small dragons instead of the originalâ€™s eaglelike birds. Disney portrays the Fair Folk as miniature winged people, where Alexander has them come in a variety of shapes and sizes. There are major plot alterations, too. Locations, power dynamics, and the storyâ€™s ending are all fluffier in Disneyâ€™s hands.

11. Beauty and the Beast (1991)

Based on: Jeanne-Marie Leprince de Beaumontâ€™s short story â€œBeauty and the Beastâ€ (1756)

If thereâ€™s a pattern to this list, itâ€™s one of Disney romanticizing and simplifying its fairy tale sources. Thereâ€™s no Gaston or LeFou in the original story, which means thereâ€™s no angry mob out to harm the Beast. LumiÃ¨re and Cogsworth are Disney inventions â€” in the original story, costumed birds and monkeys serve as Beautyâ€™s companions. A crucial piece of backstory concerning the rose is omitted on screen, and the Beastâ€™s transition to the Prince occurs halfway into the written story. For those wanting to watch a more faithful adaptation, see the 1946 live-action film of the same name directed by Jean Cocteau.

10. Meet the Robinsons (2007)

Based on: William Joyceâ€™s picture book A Day with Wilbur Robinson (1990)

With Meet the Robinsons, Disney took the book as a starting point and extrapolated from there. Joyceâ€™s A Day with Wilbur Robinson is a charming, rambling tale that really doesnâ€™t have much of a plot. Itâ€™s about the journey, not the destination, as Wilbur and his friend Lewis search through the Robinsonsâ€™ extraordinary house in search of Wilburâ€™s grandfatherâ€™s missing false teeth. Pretty much everything else on the screen was added in by Disneyâ€™s filmmaking team.

9. Pinocchio (1940)

Based on: Carlo Collodiâ€™s novel The Adventures of Pinocchio (1883)

Remember Jiminy Cricket, the narrator and crooning troubadour who gave Disney its signature song, â€œWhen You Wish Upon a Starâ€? Toward the beginning of Carlo Collodiâ€™s original childrenâ€™s book, the lovable little fella lectures the wooden puppet Pinocchio on proper behavior. Irritated, Pinocchio throws a hammer at poor Jiminy and kills him. That isnâ€™t the only radical departure from the novel, or the only grotesque violence Disneyâ€™s adaptation omits. Gepetto gets in a punch-up and is carted off to jail. Pinocchio gets his feet burned off in a fire, and heâ€™s drowned and hanged, as well as turned into a donkey. The original version is much darker, and includes a lot more magic and mutilation.

8. Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937)

Based on: The Brothers Grimmâ€™s fable â€œSnow Whiteâ€ (1812)

The original â€œSnow Whiteâ€ fairy tale is far less fluffy and romantic than the film. In the Brothers Grimmâ€™s version, the Wicked Queen doesnâ€™t ask her huntsman for Snow Whiteâ€™s heart â€” she wants her lungs and liver. Snow White isnâ€™t awakened by a princeâ€™s kiss; her coffin is dropped, which dislodges a piece of the Witchâ€™s poison apple from her body, letting her wake up again. The Grimms also have a far more distasteful end for the Wicked Queen â€” sheâ€™s forced to dance in red-hot iron shoes until she dies. Lovely.

7. Aladdin (1992)

Based on: The folk tale â€œAladdin and the Wonderful Lampâ€ from the collection One Thousand and One Nights

Disney made innumerable alterations to the centuries-old tale of Aladdin. The setting is changed from China to the Middle East, and Aladdinâ€™s parents are absent. (In the original story, Aladdinâ€™s mother plays a prominent role.) Abu and the magic carpet are both Disney inventions, as are Jafar and his parrot sidekick, Iago. The genie plays a very minor role in the folk tale. Even putting aside the songs, Robin Williamsâ€™ magnificent performance as the Genie, and his numerous pop-culture references, Disneyâ€™s version doesnâ€™t have much in common with its source except a poor boy, a magic lamp, and a genie who grants wishes.

6. The Princess and the Frog (2009)

Based on: E.D. Bakerâ€™s novel The Frog Princess (2002)

The Princess and the Frog is another case of Disney transplanting a setting wholesale, on this occasion from the medieval fantasy world of The Frog Princess to 1920s New Orleans. At the start of E.D. Bakerâ€™s book, the princess lives with her mother, Queen Chartreuse, whereas Disneyâ€™s protagonist is a humble waitress. Thatâ€™s just the start of a long list of differences. The plot bears very little resemblance to that of the book, and the novelâ€™s central message â€” about not judging by appearances â€” is replaced with one about finding the right work-life balance.

5. Tangled (2010)

Based on: The Brothers Grimmâ€™s fairy tale â€œRapunzelâ€ (1812)

Beyond the concept of a princess with long hair whoâ€™s locked in a tower, there isnâ€™t much from the Brothers Grimmâ€™s version that makes it to the screen. Rapunzel isnâ€™t a princess in the original story; her visitor at the tower is a prince; and thereâ€™s a nasty turn in the fable that sees said prince wandering in the desert, his eyes pricked out by thorns. Disney reverses the social roles, making Rapunzelâ€™s visitor a lovable thief. Almost every other plot point, including the magic hair, Mother Gothel, and the bar full of heroic reprobates, is a Disney original.

4. Oliver & Company (1988)

Based on: Charles Dickensâ€™ novel Oliver Twist (1838)

Aside from the fact that Disney transplants the action from Victorian England to 1980s New York City and replaces all the characters with talking animals, thereâ€™s barely any difference between these two stories! Seriously, though, this is about as far from the source material as you can get without completely ditching the plot. Dickensâ€™ novel was a social commentary about the plight of the working-class poor. You can imagine that book being successfully translated as a Disney classic, but Oliver & Company isnâ€™t it.

3. The Little Mermaid (1989)

Based on: Hans Christian Andersenâ€™s short story â€œThe Little Mermaidâ€ (1837)

In the original â€œLittle Mermaidâ€ story, the Ariel figure (who never gets a name) wasnâ€™t motivated by love, but by a hunger for immortality. Mermaids donâ€™t have souls, but sheâ€™s told sheâ€™ll magically get one if she marries a human man. In Andersenâ€™s world, itâ€™s completely OK for mermaids to visit the surface world once theyâ€™ve turned 15, and she leaves the sea with her familyâ€™s blessing. Andersen also describes the mermaidâ€™s transformation to her human form as an extremely painful process, and walking around on feet as an endless agony she has to suffer through. Perhaps the biggest difference is the ending. There isnâ€™t a fairy-tale wedding on the printed page: The mermaidâ€™s prince marries someone else. And while her sisters offer her a chance to return home if she murders both the prince and his new wife, she instead opts to throw herself into the sea â€” where she expects to evaporate into foam, as mermaids do when they die. She gets a different reward for her piety and mercy, though, in keeping with Andersenâ€™s usual Christian fables.

2. Chicken Little (2005)

Based on: Chicken Little, an old European folk tale

This was Disneyâ€™s first fully CGI film. In the folk story, an acorn falls on Chicken Littleâ€™s head, and he mistakenly cries out that the sky is falling. He sets off to spread his warning, recruiting various animals to his cause along the way. In most versions of the tale, a sly fox tricks the animals into visiting his den, where he eats them. Disneyâ€™s Chicken Little also has something fall on his head, but this turns out to be a fragment from an alien spaceship â€” the trigger for a plot which eventually ends with the aliens and the village folk overcoming their misunderstandings to become friends. Aside from the narrative device of something falling on Chicken Littleâ€™s head, there really are no elements of plot or theme which unite the story and the movie.

1. The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996)

Based on: Victor Hugoâ€™s novel The Hunchback of Notre-Dame (1831)

Where to start with this one? Victor Hugoâ€™s Phoebus (voiced by Kevin Kline in the movie) is a sleazy player, not at all the heroic and compassionate hero of Disneyâ€™s adaptation. The villain Frollo is a man of the church, not a judge. In the novel, Esmeralda is hanged for attempted murder and Frollo is killed by Quasimodo, who himself dies from starvation while pining over Esmeraldaâ€™s grave. Disney also left out an important subplot concerning Esmeraldaâ€™s origins. In the book, Esmeralda, born to a prostitute, is kidnapped as a baby, with the infant Quasimodo substituted in her place. In summary, the novel is a somewhat cynical tale of misplaced passions leading to bad endings, wrapped up with some wry humor concerning the human condition. Disneyâ€™s version is a straight-up good-versus-evil love story.
